page.title: 08National Trust in Silverdale
page.content: Jack Scout, which probably means oaktree cliff, was acquired by the National Trust in 1982. The money was raised by an enthusiastic local committee and a grant from Enterprise Neptune. It is a pleasant, wild, rocky area on cliffs overlooking the sea on the eastern verge of Morecambe Bay. The walls and an old limekiln were repaired during these years by the National Trust with the help of the Manpower Services Commission. Many men and boys learned dry stone walling techniques and some have since set up in business on their own. The area is used mainly for walking and is let to a farmer, who keeps it grazed as there are a number of rare plants which thrive in short turf. Paths pass through the gorse used by small birds as nesting sites.
